preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-7.5 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with full sun receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start Basil seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-02-01 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.25 inches deep with 8 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-02-01 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water Basil deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect Basil weekly for common zone 8a-11 pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting Basil approximately 65 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Basil at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for herb type

preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-6.8 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with full sun receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start Tomato seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-02-01 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.25 inches deep with 24 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-02-01 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water Tomato deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect Tomato weekly for common zone 8a-11 pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting Tomato approximately 75 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Tomato at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

plant_groupings.spacing_notes: Plant Basil 8 inches apart, and Tomatoes 24-36 inches apart to allow for air circulation

general_tips: Basil is a warm-season crop that thrives in the long growing season of Beverly Hills. Plant it in well-draining soil with full sun (at least 6 hours of direct sunlight) and keep the temperature between 60-80°F.
Tomatoes love the warm weather in Beverly Hills, but they need support to grow upright. Use tomato cages or trellises to keep them off the ground and promote healthy growth.
In the hot summer months, water your plants deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. This will help them survive during periods of drought.
Basil is a heavy feeder and needs regular fertilization. Use a balanced fertilizer (10-10-10) once a month to keep it healthy and pest-free.
Tomatoes are prone to pests like hornworms and aphids in the Beverly Hills area. Keep an eye out for these pests and use organic pesticides if necessary.
In the cooler winter months, protect your plants from frost by covering them with a sheet or bringing potted plants indoors.
